Comment: This is the starting position of the mini-tournament; White has adopted the stonewall setup, characterised by the pawns on c3, d4, e3 and f4. In this opening, White wants to post a knight on e5 and create a lot of pressure on the kingside.

Pawn exchange. I take with the e pawn so that 9...Nb4 is not an option for black.
Pawn exchange. I take with the e pawn so that 9...Nb4 is not an option for black.
Minor piece exchange. Whilst the knights are generally better than bishops in a closed position, this is actually an inaccuracy from Black. I attack the knight with my pawn...
Minor piece exchange. Whilst the knights are generally better than bishops in a closed position, this is actually an inaccuracy from Black. I attack the knight with my pawn...
And Black is forced to retreat the knight behind the pawn structure, on the queenside. White's objective is to attack the kingside, so there is one less defender now!
I castle to get my rook on the semi-open f file.
Black puts pressure on my b and d pawns. This also pins my d pawn, allowing Black to capture my advanced e pawn with either of his knight on the next turn.
However, I simply step out of the pin. My b pawn is still protected for now.
Black now threatens to break my central pawn chain. However, I have a nifty trick that allows me to keep the position closed.
! I threaten mate on h7. (14.Bxh7+ Kh8 15.Bg6+ Kg8 16.Qh7#)
Black blocks the b1-h7 diagonal, blunting my bishop. However, this also means that I have a very strong pawn on e5!
I bring more pieces to the attack.
And black brings more pieces to the defence!
I threaten mate on h7 once again.
Forced.
!? A gutsy move. I sacrifice my knight so I can get a rook-queen battery on the h file faster.
Black accepts the sacrifice.

Just as planned. I do not threaten mate. However, Black's kingside is paralysed. His g7 pawn cannot move due to Qh7#, his rook cannot move around without losing material or getting mated, both knights have no useful squares to go on the kingside, etc.
Black attacks my rook.
I move my rook to h4. I also threaten the g pawn, as the f pawn is pinned to the h7 square.
